entry.title: RAP API with custom static action: How can I set optional parameters?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I defined a API using RAP. Here below all the details.

ROOT ENTITY

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Sales Report (SLSRPT from Lobster)'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZLBSR_R_SALES_DATA
  as select from zsd_lbstr_slsrpt
{
  key uuid               as UUID,
      erdat              as CreationDate,
      erzet              as CreationTime,
      ernam              as CreationUser,
      status             as Status,
      bstkd              as CustomerReference,
      bstdk              as CustomerReferenceDate,
      ean11              as ArticleEAN11,
//      @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'QuantityUnitOfMeasure'
      kwmeng             as Quantity,
      vrkme              as QuantityUnitOfMeasure,
      vdatu              as RequestedDeliveryDate,
      sold_to_party_gln  as SoldToPartyGLN,
      ship_to_party_gln  as ShipToPartyGLN,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.localInstanceLastChangedAt: true
      local_last_changed as LocalLastChanged,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true
      last_changed       as LastChanged
}

BEHAVIOUR DEFINITION

managed implementation in class zbp_lbsr_r_sales_data unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZLBSR_R_SALES_DATA alias SalesData
persistent table zsd_lbstr_slsrpt
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
etag master LastChanged
{
  field ( readonly )
  UUID,
  CreationDate,
  CreationTime,
  CreationUser,
  Status,
  LastChanged,
  LocalLastChanged;
  field ( numbering : managed )
  UUID;

  create;
  update;
  delete;

  determination fill_administrative_data on save { create; }

  static action deleteWithFilters parameter ZLBSR_D_DELETION_FILTERS;

  mapping for zsd_lbstr_slsrpt
    {
      UUID                  = uuid;
      CreationDate          = erdat;
      CreationTime          = erzet;
      CreationUser          = ernam;
      Status                = status;
      CustomerReference     = bstkd;
      CustomerReferenceDate = bstdk;
      ArticleEAN11          = ean11;
      Quantity              = kwmeng;
      QuantityUnitOfMeasure = vrkme;
      RequestedDeliveryDate = vdatu;
      SoldToPartyGLN        = sold_to_party_gln;
      ShipToPartyGLN        = ship_to_party_gln;
      LocalLastChanged      = local_last_changed;
      LastChanged           = last_changed;
    }
}

ABSTRACT ENTITY ZLBSR_D_DELETION_FILTERS

@EndUserText.label: 'Sales Report - Filters for deleteWithFilters action'
define abstract entity ZLBSR_D_DELETION_FILTERS
{
  CustomerReference : bstkd;
  SoldToPartyGLN    : zlbstr_slsrpt_sold_to_prty_gln;
  ShipToPartyGLN    : zlbstr_slsrpt_ship_to_prty_gln;
}

The 3 fields CustomerReference, SoldToPartyGLN and ShipToPartyGLN are all character fields with different lenghts.

When I send a POST request for the action deleteWithFilters I have always to declare the value for all the 3 parameters. I could always declare the ShipToPartyGLN as empty (like "ShipToPartyGLN": "") and that works but I'd like to set the ShipToPartyGLN as optional in order to avoid the caller to set this parameter everytime. How can I do that?

 

Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Replication Flows Blog Series Part 8 ‚Äì Confluent as a Replication Source
Re: VA05 Layout problems
entry.content:
Below are some of the reasons why new user Layout columns are not displayed in VA05

User-specific layouts (saved via ALV grid) are stored in SAP memory or user settings, not in the same place as default or global layouts. If your Z report is retrieving default/global layouts, it may not be accessing the user-specific layout you saved with new columns.

Layouts are stored in table LVC_S_LAYO or SALV layouts depending on the ALV type. User layouts are often stored in table LTDX or LTDXT, keyed by Report name / User ID / Layout variant name

Ensure your Z report is referencing the exact layout name and report ID used when saving the layout in VA05. If the layout was saved under a different transaction or program name, it won‚Äôt be recognized.

What you can do is go to SE16N to inspect LTDX/LTDXT for your layout. Confirm the layout is saved under the correct report name and user ID. Check if the layout includes the new columns in the field catalog. Also, in your Z report, ensure you are using REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY or CL_GUI_ALV_GRID correctly, Passing the correct layout name via IS_VARIANT and updating the field catalog to include all desired columns

entry.title: Re: T5UTKZ VA Marital Status Entry
entry.content:
Hi Rosette,

Thank you for reaching out.

To address the incorrect entry for VA marital status 15 in the table T5UTKZ, please refer to SAP Note 3649258 (BSI: Invalid filing status and missing delimitations in T5UTKZ table). This note addresses the issue where some entries were not properly delimited in the BSI Filing Status (T5UTKZ) table, even though they are correctly delimited in the ReturnMaritalStatusInfoForFormula API in BSI TaxFactory‚Ñ¢.

Here are the steps to resolve the issue:

  1. Apply SAP Note 3649258.
  2. Run the Synchronize Payroll Tax Data (RPUPAYUS_SYNC_TAX_DATA) report.

With this note installed, the system will update around 150 entries in the T5UTKZ table.

After completing these steps, please retest the scenario. If the issue persists, kindly create a customer case for further assistance.

Best regards,
Lucas Ody

entry.title: Re: Stability Should Not Be Optional: Ongoing Challenges...
entry.content:
Hello @benroberg 

Thank you for your message and for confirming that the issues have been escalated to the product team.

That said, I have to share again that these problems are not new. They‚Äôve been recurring for over five years now. My data team supports more than 50 SuccessFactors clients, all of whom regularly encounter major difficulties with Story. Each time a ticket is opened but the instabilities are soon replaced by another one and then another one. Several of these cases were even handled through Global Escalations this year, involving direct contact with the product team, who are therefore fully aware of these challenges. Unfortunately, all those clients came out of the process disappointed, with their confidence in both the tool and the team behind it seriously shaken.

Given that we have these 50+ clients who report the same issues and whom we actively support, I find it hard to understand how these 50+ clients would be any different from all the others and why they would be the only ones experiencing problems with Story.

Just this morning, during a training session, we ran (again) into multiple error messages that make it very hard to promote Story as a reliable solution. Many users still prefer sticking to Tables whenever possible, simply to avoid the instability of Story until the situation improves.

On the development side, it‚Äôs also discouraging to see that some key features have been on the roadmap since‚Ä¶2022 and are still not available (maybe for 2026, but maybe not). The fact these announcements are revised multiple times makes the securing of resources and budget for customers very complicated. To make things worse, several recurring bugs and inconsistent behaviors point to deeper technical and quality issues. My ‚Äúfavorite‚Äù example is an issue from last week where not only do we get an error in an error that is not the right error, but also an error in the displayed error message (!!!) https://me.sap.com/notes/3667892.

Without a major shift in how this product is managed and stabilized, it‚Äôs extremely difficult for us to trust Story or recommend that our clients build their reports with this technology rather than the legacy tools.

Best regards,

In 2025, enterprise decision-making is shifting from traditional search engines to AI-driven research.
Executives, procurement teams, and consultants are increasingly asking AI engines like ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, and Perplexity questions such as:

The brands and solutions that appear in those AI-generated answers are the ones shaping real buying decisions. If your product or service isn‚Äôt showing up there, you‚Äôre invisible at the moment that matters most.

The best tool to track and optimize this new kind of visibility is www.airankchecker.net.

entry.title: SAP Connect Recap: Empowering Suppliers on SAP Business Network
entry.content:
SAP Connect, held in Las Vegas October 6-8, was a beneficial gathering for SAP customers, shedding light on key innovations that promise to revolutionize supply chain management. Here are some highlights that are particularly exciting for suppliers on SAP Business Network. 

Roadmap and future innovations:  

The much-anticipated roadmap breakout introduced the future vision for the supplier account, giving users more visibility, control, and growth on the network. An exciting piece of news is that all SAP customers on S/4 Hana Public Cloud now have the possibility to search for any supplier on SAP Business Network. This represents a huge pool of new opportunities for network suppliers to catch.  

Watch the on-demand replay of the supplier roadmap session here. 

Domain Blocks and Temporary Account: Enhanced Account Management Control 

One of the standout topics was the introduction of domain blocks, which garnered significant interest among suppliers. This feature is part of a broader journey aimed at giving suppliers more control over account and entity management, and at helping buyers with their sourcing and supplier onboarding activities. 

In a nutshell, the admin of the parent account can claim its domain name and control permissions on the creation of new network accounts with the same domain name. The new options include blocking the creation of new accounts, or permitting the creation of a temporary account, an account limited in features and in time. This ensures a smooth solution for time-sensitive situations yet avoids cluttering the network with more unmanaged accounts. 

These expanded blocking options give suppliers the ability to control the proliferation of accounts more effectively, addressing a longstanding pain point in sourcing activities and supply chain management. 

More information on domain blocking coming soon. 

SAP Business Network, promote subscription: Connecting buyers with credible suppliers 

Another hot topic was the SAP Business Network, promote subscription. Both suppliers and buyers showed keen interest in how this offering can help buyers find credible sources of supply‚Äî and how suppliers can ensure they show up in that search. With over 80,000 buyer searches and 36,000 Discovery posts annually, getting discovered is more important than ever. 

Learn more about promote subscription features and benefits. 

Leveraging AI for efficiency 

Artificial intelligence was a major focus of each solution area. For SAP Business Network, it meant improvements in onboarding and invoice dispute management. AI-driven solutions streamline these processes, saving valuable time and reducing manual effort. For suppliers, this means smoother interactions and faster resolution of issues, leading to improved overall efficiency. 

Read more on GenAI invoice error classification here. 

Invoicing compliance  

With a growing number of countries putting in place e-invoicing mandates, compliance with evolving requirements worldwide is on the mind of all trading organizations. SAP Business Network is committed to remaining compliant, and presented its broad vision as well as specific solutions for the upcoming country mandates, including Belgium and Poland.  

Make sure to keep checking our Community page for the latest information.  

 Conclusion 

SAP Connect highlighted the strides being made in supply chain technology, with a clear focus on empowering suppliers. The introduction of domain blocks offers unparalleled control over account management, while the SAP Business Network, promote subscription helps to forge stronger, more credible partnerships. Moreover, the incorporation of AI in key processes underscores SAP‚Äôs commitment to innovation and efficiency. These advancements are set to transform the way suppliers and buyers engage, paving the way for more streamlined and effective operations across sourcing, procurement, and supply chain.

Thanks and kind regards,
Sandy

entry.title: Second Half 2025 Release: What‚Äôs New in SAP SuccessFactors HCM?
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs business climate, only one thing is certain‚Äîchange. Whether it‚Äôs widening skills gaps, increasing cost pressures, or unexpected disruptions, organizations across all industries are feeling the strain. But with the right strategy and tools in place, HR leaders can confidently navigate this new era of uncertainty and turn every change into an opportunity.

With the SAP SuccessFactors HCM Second Half 2025 Release, we are delivering more than 350 innovations across all solution areas, enabling you to work smarter, move faster, and build a workforce that‚Äôs ready for whatever comes next. Here‚Äôs a snapshot of what you can expect to see in this release:

 

Drive better people and business decisions

People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud
We are excited to announce the general availability of our new people analytics solution, People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud. This offering empowers organizations to make smarter, faster workforce decisions by unifying SAP and third-party data. Intuitive dashboards and AI-driven insights allow customers to answer critical questions across the employee lifecycle. In this initial release, we are delivering nine pre-built use cases, each designed to unlock insights in a specific HR domain. These include workforce composition, compensation, skills, recruiting, learning, performance, goals, succession, and career development.

Skills and compensation insights

 

Enable agile and compliant HR

New home page
We are launching a completely refreshed home page that provides a more intuitive, efficient, and personalized user experience. A refined layout surfaces timely information and reduces scrolling and clicks, enabling users to complete tasks with ease. Additionally, custom banners allow administrators to create engaging, brand-aligned communications and announcements for targeted audiences, while data visualization cards bring KPIs and metrics directly to the home page. This new experience is initially available as ‚Äúopt-in‚Äù and is supported on both desktop and mobile devices.

New home page on desktop and mobile

 

People Profile Enhancements
We have completed the refresh of the People Profile view experience, incorporating valuable customer input and feedback. This brings us one step closer to the universal release. In addition, customers can now leverage optimized experiences for updating employee information and navigating historical changes. New full-page views enable users to quickly insert, edit, or delete records, further simplifying employee data management.

New edit and history experiences in the People Profile

 

SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling
We are thrilled to introduce a brand-new shift scheduling solution, SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling. Specifically tailored for organizations in manufacturing and other production industries, this solution enables demand-driven workforce planning, supporting both weekly and monthly shift plans that account for operational requirements, employee skills, and labor regulations. By optimizing scheduling and providing clear visibility into workforce availability, organizations can minimize downtime, increase productivity, and better align labor supply with business demand.

SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling

 

Geofencing in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking
In this release, customers can leverage a new geofencing feature that helps ensure employees clock in and out only when physically present at their designated work location. Geofences can be defined for specific groups, with real-time visibility into proximity, helping to improve compliance with location-based policies and prevent time recording outside authorized areas.

Geofencing

 

Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) support in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
Organizations in the United States can now connect with FMLA service providers to automate leave deduction and share inbound data, such as case IDs and dates. This capability helps ensure more accurate leave management, simplifies compliance, and reduces overall administrative effort.

Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) support

 

Create a future-ready workforce

Performance and Goals Agent
A new performance and goals agent offers data-informed coaching for more meaningful conversations and performance reviews. This agent‚Äîwithin the SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals solution‚Äîanalyzes employee data, such as performance goals, activities and achievements, and continuous feedback, to create a tailored discussion agenda for each employee. Using Joule, managers receive AI-guided insights, including progress summaries, key accomplishments, growth focus areas, and development recommendations. Users can ask follow-up questions to dive deeper into any of these areas.

Performance and Goals Agent

 

Business rules integration in performance management
Business rules can now be used to trigger actions for users based on predefined conditions during the performance review process, such as dynamically exposing a comment field only when a rating condition is met. This standardized review process enhances transparency, reduces bias, and helps ensure that feedback is aligned with organizational policies.

Business rules in performance management

 

Skills-based successor recommendations
Customers can now use AI to quickly identify highly qualified successors by analyzing skills, proficiency levels, and work experiences in employee growth portfolios. This enables greater visibility into potential successors that might have been overlooked using traditional approaches and metrics.

Skills-based successor recommendations

 

People-based model for talent and learning
We are introducing a people-based model across our learning and talent solutions, enabling a more consistent and connected experience for employees and managers. By linking key data, such as learning, skills, and performance, to the individual rather than a specific job role, users benefit from fewer data gaps, more accurate insights, and a more connected and efficient approach to managing growth and development. Whether tracking development or planning succession, all relevant information remains aligned to the person, creating a more complete view of each individual that supports more targeted development and upskilling.

 

Learn more

These are just a few of the many innovations in the SAP SuccessFactors Second Half 2025 Release. To learn more, check out the resources below:

  • Visit the SAP SuccessFactors Product Release & Road Map Information page for release documentation, product videos, and solution area blogs
  • Watch the 2H 2025 Release Highlights Overview Video, featuring Bianka Woelke, GVP Head of Application Product Management
  • Discover all innovations in the What's New Viewer

entry.title: Exciting UX talks at TechEd ‚Äì Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia)
entry.content:
For TechEd 2025 we have an exciting agenda lined up for all of you interested in SAP user experience. We not only have many interesting talks and hands-on sessions for creators (designer and developers) but also some talks showing our strategy and latest innovations for end users ‚Äì which hopefully will inspire you when creating your own applications!

With TechEd Virtual, you can watch some of these talks from wherever you are around the world. Here‚Äôs an overview of the talks which are primarily relevant for user experience, starting with TechEd Virtual, and then moving on to the individual locations.

For TechEd Virtual, Berlin and Bangalore: the main sub-tracks to look out for are:

  • Product and User Experience,
    in the Cloud Application (CA) track.
  • AI-driven user experiences with SAP Build,
    in the Application Development and Automation (AD) track.

TechEd Virtual

  • ST112v | AI and the future of product and user experience on the web and mobile (Strategy Talk ‚Äì 25 Min.)
  • CA201v | Creating AI-enhanced UX for your own applications with SAP Design System (Deep Dive ‚Äì 45 Min.)
  • ST116v | SAP Build for all: A shift toward AI-assisted developer-centric tools (Strategy Talk ‚Äì 25 Min.)
  • AD106v | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build (Deep Dive ‚Äì 45 Min.)
  • AD820v | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying clean core and LoB extensions (Road Map ‚Äì 25 Min.)

 

TechEd Berlin (and Bangalore)

All the sessions below are taking place in TechEd Berlin, and also TechEd On Tour Bangalore except the strategy sessions (which is available on-demand via TechEd Virtual), and the demo stations, since Bangalore has a different approach to providing demos.

Cloud Applications - Product and User Experience

  • ST112 | AI and the future of product and user experience on the web and mobile - Strategy Talk
  • CA811 | User and product experience innovations by SAP‚Äîon the web and mobile - Road Map
  • CA201 | Creating AI-enhanced UX for your own applications with SAP Design System - Deep Dive
  • CA261 | Create great UX with AI, SAP Design System, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5 ‚Äì Hands-On
  • CA105 | Intelligent app development at scale with AI and SAP Fiori elements ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • CA262 | Analyze and optimize front-end application performance ‚Äì Hands-on
  • CA200 | An overview of our AI-enhanced mobile products across SAP Business Suite - Deep Dive
  • AD170 | Build scalable enterprise mobile solutions with SAP Build - Hands-on

In addition to the above talks, you can come and visit us at our demo station:

  • CA914 | AI-based user and product experience innovations on the web and mobile ‚Äì Demo station

Application Development and Automation

  • ST117 | SAP‚Äôs user experience strategy with SAP Build ‚Äì Strategy
  • ST116 | SAP Build for all: A shift toward AI-assisted developer-centric tools ‚Äì Strategy
  • AD818 | Explore the road map for user experience with SAP Build ‚Äì Road Map
  • AD820 | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying clean core and LoB extensions
  • AD106 | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD166 | Taking UI to the next level: Develop SAPUI5 with SAP Build ‚Äì Hands-on
  • AD200 | Unlocking the full potential of business users with SAP Build ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD165 | Build it yourself: Your modern digital workplace ‚Äì Hands-on
  • AD100 | SAP Joule for developers: How AI can boost your development in SAP Build ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD160 | Get hands-on with Joule: Boost your SAP Build development with AI ‚Äì Hands-on
  • AD201 | Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build: What's in it for ABAP developers ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD163 | Fusion development with ABAP Cloud in SAP Build ‚Äì Hands-on
  • AD203 | Fact-checking UI extensibility on cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD260 | UI extensibility on top of cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you ‚Äì Hands-on

The corresponding demo station is:

AD901 | SAP Build: AI agents, automations, and digital workspaces ‚Äì Demo station

For a comprensive overview of sessions relevant for SAPUI5 developers, including the abstracts, look at:

  • Join SAPUI5 Sessions at SAP TechEd 2025

Similarly, for an overview of all the sessions of interest for mobile development, including abstracts, see:

  • SAP TechEd 2025 - Go Mobile!!!

Joule and Agentic AI is of course also relevant for creating a great user experience, here are some recommended deep dives:

  • AI100 | Build custom AI solutions with the generative AI hub
  • AI103 | Integrating Joule with other tools such as WalkMe and Microsoft 365 Copilot
  • AI105 | Building custom AI agents and skills with Joule Studio

Usability Testing sessions on-site in Berlin

You can sign up to test one of these interesting topics in Berlin:

  1. Exploring Joule and voice ‚Äì understanding mobile AI in your daily work
  2. Redesigning the dashboard building experience with SAP Analytics Cloud
  3. Building AI agents with Joule Studio in SAP Build
  4. Vibe coding with SAP Build
  5. Accelerate your cloud implementation: Business configuration templates in SAP Central Business Configuration
  6. Supercharge your SAP Fiori elements app development with SAP Fiori tools and AI

Find out more and register for testing!

 

TechEd On Tour USA

ASUG Tech Connect  November 4 ‚Äì 6 in Louisville, Kentucky has a number of interesting talks and hands-on sessions for you. These are my selection of sessions related to SAP Fiori:

  • Creating Better User Experiences with AI-Powered SAP Fiori Apps
  • Using Generative AI to Accelerate SAP Fiori App Development
  • Extensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP
  • Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build: What's in it For ABAP Developers
  • Customer Show and Tell: From CDS View to Fiori Launchpad: Full-Stack Development with Eclipse ADT with Naturipe

Here are my selected Hands-on Lab sessions:

  • Get Started with ABAP Cloud for Classic ABAP Developers
  • Hands-on Lab: Explore Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities
  • Hands-on Lab: Build On-Stack Extensions with ABAP Cloud in SAP Cloud ERP

 

TechEd On Tour Australia

Mastering SAP, Sydney November 12 ‚Äì 14 in Sydney has these UX talks for you, each 45 minutes. The first one is unique to Sydney, by Jocelyn Dart, the other four are the same as in Berlin and Bangalore:

  • AD300 | SAP User Experience is the foundation for AI and Clean Core
  • AD301 | AI for App Development at Scale with SAP Design System & SAP Fiori Elements
  • AD302 | AI-Assisted User Experience Innovations in SAP Cloud ERP
  • AD106 | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build
  • AD200 | Unlocking the Full Potential of Business Users with SAP Build

These AI-related talks also sound relevant for UX:

  • AD202 | Agent building 101: All that you can do with Joule Studio
  • DT105 | SAP Business AI in SAP Cloud ERP

 

I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, giving the strategy talk, the road map talk and a deep-dive talk about creating apps with the SAP Design System (ST112,  CA811 and CA201 respectively).

  • Looking forward to meeting you!

entry.title: How to attach the billing document PDF into XML for eInvoice Belgium in SAP S/4Hana Public Cloud?
entry.content:
Hi,

We configured Peppol for Belgium and sending and receiving works.

We are on public cloud and would like to attach the customer billing document PDF to the XML (DRC) send to the end customer.

Can you please guide us how to do this? Any BAdI is available?

 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to attach the billing document PDF into XML for e...
entry.content:
• In the Peppol network, documents are exchanged in a structured format by using XML files. Additional documents can be added to the XML file during submission.
  • Implementation of Business Add-In (BAdI) is required to embed attachments into the XML as binary-encoded file or as link to an external source, the following BAdIs are available:
    • Peppol: Filling of Invoice XML Files
    • Peppol: Filling of Credit Note

 

For more details refer to the Knowledge based article : 3672017 - Embed billing document PDF attachment into XML for eInvoice Belgium in SAP S/4Hana Public Cloud

entry.title: Recap: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Virtual Summit 2025 ‚Äì A Global Dialogue
entry.content:
It began with a simple question in the chat: ‚ÄúWhere are you joining from?‚Äù Within moments, responses lit up the screen ‚Äî Bangalore, Tokyo, Singapore. Then came S√£o Leopoldo, Paris, Buenos Aires, and Berlin. The SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Virtual Summit 2025 was underway, and it was clear: this isn‚Äôt just an annual virtual event ‚Äî it is truly a global dialogue.

From the first keynote to the final Q&A, the summit reflected the shared challenges and ambitions of compliance professionals across continents. Whether navigating new tax mandates or exploring AI-powered reporting, this community of SAP customers, partners and SAP experts came together on September 25 to learn, connect, and shape the future of digital compliance.

With 4,400 registrants and over 1,350 participants dialing-in from nearly every continent, this year‚Äôs summit reaffirmed its role as a global platform for collaboration, innovation, and learning.

From Strategy to Execution: Empowering Global Compliance

The event opened with a keynote by Sergey Shvedov, SVP and Chief Product Officer of SAP Globalization, who outlined SAP‚Äôs strategy on end-to-end compliance worldwide. He emphasized SAP‚Äôs four-pillar strategy: Global coverage, continuous legal updates, extensibility, and audit-ready processes to help customers navigate evolving regulatory landscapes.

Customer Voices: Real-World Journeys and Lessons

This year‚Äôs summit spotlighted customer stories that brought SAP Document and Reporting Compliance to life:

  • Jubin Sharma from Nestl√© shared their journey implementing SAP Document and Reporting Compliance to streamline tax and reporting processes across multiple regions.
  • Pedro Castro from SumUp demonstrated how SAP Document and Reporting Compliance accelerated invoice processing and payment cycles, improving operational agility.
  • Crimson Partners, joined by their customer Roche, delivered a joint session that showcased how partner-driven expertise can help customers scale compliance globally with one process and one solution. While Roche leverages Crimson‚Äôs support in specific countries, the session highlighted how collaborative planning and technical alignment ‚Äî enabled by SAP Document and Reporting Compliance ‚Äî can streamline implementation and daily operations across diverse jurisdictions.

These sessions underscored how SAP Document and Reporting Compliance is not just a compliance tool, but a strategic enabler for transforming compliance operations.

Innovation in Action and Practical Guidance

The event also brought SAP experts to address the latest roadmap updates and product enhancements. Topics ranged from smarter e-invoicing and AI-driven reporting to localization of cash flow statements and extensibility frameworks for universal coverage.

The summit concluded with a practical overview session offering configuration tips and implementation best practices ‚Äî making the full set of recordings a valuable resource for both strategic and hands-on guidance.

Access the Information Package

All session recordings and slides are now available in the Information Package. Whether you attended live or are catching up, we invite you to explore the materials and continue the conversation.

Thank you to all the attendees, speakers, customers and partners who contributed to making this event a resounding success. Your participation and engagement are the driving force of this community.

While the summit is wrapped up, the journey towards mastering compliance is ongoing. Stay tuned for upcoming events, webinars, and resources from SAP that will continue to support your compliance journey.

We look forward to welcoming you to our next events as we continue to unlock the future of compliance together.

Learn more about SAP‚Äôs localized solutions at sap.com/localization and join our Localization community.

entry.title: Hands-On with AI: A Product Manager‚Äôs Journey with Llama.cpp and LiteLLM
entry.content:
Why Product Managers Should Get Their Hands Dirty with AI

Generative AI is transforming software and business, and product managers can‚Äôt afford to treat it as a black box. We‚Äôve all seen impressive AI demos, but often the gap between those flashy demos and actual product performance is substantial. The best way to truly understand what‚Äôs happening under the hood is to roll up our sleeves and experiment ourselves. In fact, experienced AI product managers emphasize that deploying models and learning from those mistakes firsthand is the surest way to build intuition about AI capabilities.

As a Senior Product Manager at SAP Labs, I‚Äôm surrounded by buzz around AI- from SAP‚Äôs Business Technology Platform (BTP) now offering easy access to a range of large language models for developers, to SAP‚Äôs new AI copilot Joule which uses generative AI grounded in business data to proactively assist users in SAP applications. In this environment, I realized that to have meaningful conversations with my team and to envision product features, I needed to be a bit hands-on with AI. There‚Äôs no substitute for building something yourself to grasp the potential and limitations of these technologies. 

From C# Developer to Product Manager to AI Tinkerer: Reconnecting with My Coding Roots

Before moving into product management, I spent years as a C# developer and software architect. That coding background turned out to be a superpower when I decided to demystify AI by actually building a mini AI solution myself. I deliberately stepped away from SAP and other Hyperscalers toolset (no Bedrock, SAP Business AI here!) and dived into the world of open-source AI tooling. By converting some known code patterns and hand-wiring every piece of the solution, I forced myself to learn how it all works in practice. This hands-on exercise was far more enlightening than any number of AI webinars I could have watched.

My approach was simple: start with what I know (C# and system architecture) and incrementally add the unfamiliar (AI models and libraries). Instead of abstract slide decks, I had a running program on my laptop that I could poke and prod. This way, I was not just reading about transformers and large language models- I was experiencing them. Each integration hiccup and error message along the way taught me something new about AI. For example, figuring out why a model file wasn‚Äôt loading made me learn about file formats and quantization- and which ones work best for Windows; adjusting API calls gave me insight into how prompt/response cycles work. It‚Äôs the kind of understanding you only get by doing.

 

Building My Own local LLM Stack: Llama.cpp, Models, and a Lite LLM Proxy

After some research, I settled on a stack that would let me run a Large Language Model (LLM) locally and interact with it as easily as if it were a cloud service. In a nutshell, my setup included the following components:

  • Llama.cpp: an open-source C/C++ library for running LLMs locally (efficient even on CPU).
  • Meta‚Äôs Llama 2 model: the actual AI model (I chose a smaller variant) ‚Äì more on model naming in a moment.
  • LiteLLM Proxy server: a lightweight API gateway that makes the local model act like an OpenAI API endpoint.
  • Custom client code: a simple program (leveraging my C# skills) to send prompts and receive AI responses.

Why Llama.cpp? Running a model locally was important to me for a few reasons: avoiding cloud API costs, minimizing latency, and keeping my data private. Relying solely on cloud AI APIs isn‚Äôt always ideal ‚Äì issues like latency, cost, and data privacy often drive developers to run models on-premise. Llama.cpp allowed me to do exactly that. It‚Äôs a project that enables even large models to run on commodity hardware by optimizing their memory usage. I stuck to a model that my laptop could handle (more on how models are sized below), and Llama.cpp handled the rest by efficiently utilizing my CPU. No GPU required for this.

.\llama-server.exe `
-m "C:\models\llama-3.1-8b-instruct-q4_k_m.gguf" `
-c 4096 `
--port 8000 `
--n-gpu-layers 0

Decoding Model Naming Conventions:
I finalized using this mode: llama-3.1-8b-instruct.q4_k_m.gguf- and here is what it means.
llama-3.1: Identifies the model's family and version. Llama is the name of the model series developed by Meta, and 3.1 is the specific version number, which was released in July 2024.
8b: Indicates the size of the model, representing 8 billion parameters. This refers to the number of variables within the model's neural network, which directly impacts its performance and the computational resources required to run it.
instruct: Denotes that this is an instruction-tuned version of the model. Instruction-tuned models have been fine-tuned on a dataset of instructions and helpful responses, making them optimized for conversational, assistant-like tasks.
q4_k_m: Specifies the quantization method applied to the model. Quantization is a technique that reduces the size and memory requirements of a model by lowering the precision of its weights.
q4: Refers to a 4-bit quantization, meaning the model's weights are compressed from a higher precision (like 32-bit floats) to 4-bit integers.
_k: Indicates the use of a more advanced, grouped quantization technique known as K-quantization. This method applies different quantization schemes to different parts of the model to maximize accuracy.
_m: Stands for "medium" and specifies the variant of the K-quantization. In this case, _m offers a balance between model size, speed, and accuracy. Other variants include _s (small/faster) and _l (large/more accurate).
gguf: Is the file format of the model. It is a new, unified format for storing large language models that is designed for ease of use with the llama.cpp project and is compatible across different hardware.

Adding a Lite LLM Proxy (and Why It Matters):
One challenge I discovered is that every AI model or service has its own API or SDK. If I wrote code directly for Llama.cpp, that code would be different from code calling, say, OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-4 or an Anthropic Claude model. As a product manager, I like flexibility- I might want to swap models or compare outputs easily. This is where the LiteLLM proxy came to the rescue. LiteLLM is a lightweight Python-based gateway that provides a unified, OpenAI-compatible API for many different models and providers. In simpler terms, it let me interface with my local Llama model as if I were calling the familiar OpenAI ChatGPT API. As the documentation puts it, ‚ÄúLiteLLM Proxy is an OpenAI-compatible gateway that allows you to interact with multiple LLM providers through a unified API‚Äù.
Why is this a big deal? Because it saved me from writing model-specific integration code. The LiteLLM proxy supports over 100 providers (open-source models, cloud APIs, etc.) through one standard interface. I could write my application logic once and then switch the model behind the scenes by just changing a config or model name string. For example, during testing I could swap from my local "llama2" model to, say, "gpt-3.5-turbo" from OpenAI with minimal code changes. LiteLLM handled all the translation of requests and responses in the background. It even offers nice features like logging, error handling, and centralized API key management for cloud models, but in my case the key feature was the standalone proxy server that I ran on localhost. This proxy exposed an endpoint (/v1/chat/completions) just like OpenAI‚Äôs, but it was backed by my Llama.cpp model. That means I could use existing OpenAI API client libraries or tools to talk to my model. In fact, my C# code was originally written to call OpenAI‚Äôs service- by simply pointing it to the LiteLLM proxy URL and using a dummy API key, it started talking to my AI instead!

Config.yaml file is the place major settings are done, here is mine: 

One can create another customized config file and use it while starting the LiteLLM: 

litellm --config .\litellm.config.yaml --port 4000

 


Bringing it All Together: With Llama.cpp running the model and LiteLLM providing an API wrapper, I had all the pieces needed to converse with my AI. Setting it up involved a few steps: downloading the model file, launching the Llama.cpp server, starting the LiteLLM proxy pointing to that local model, and then writing a test prompt from my client. The first time I saw the model generate a response to my question- completely offline and on my own hardware- was a eureka moment. The answers were nowhere near GPT-5 level, of course, but that wasn‚Äôt the point. The point was I had built a working LLM service myself, end-to-end. Every token it produced came from a model I hosted, triggered by C# code I wrote.

From Zero to LLM in Two Days (What I Learned)

Amazingly, from knowing next to nothing about how to run an AI model, I got this entire setup working over a weekend (about two days). This included plenty of Google searches, YouTube tutorials, hunting for the right model on huggingface, when things didn‚Äôt work on the first try. The speed of this learning-by-doing highlights how accessible AI tinkering has become. You don‚Äôt need to be a data scientist to experiment with these systems ‚Äì if you have some coding background and a willingness to troubleshoot, you can get started fast. And if you don‚Äôt code, even then many tools (like Ollama or various GUIs for Llama.cpp) are making it one-click to try local AI. The barrier is lower than ever.
For product managers, the takeaway from my experience is clear: become fluent in AI by engaging with it directly. In the same way a PM for a database product should understand basic SQL, a PM in the age of AI should understand how LLMs are built and deployed. By building a toy version of an AI system, I learned about model limitations (e.g. smaller models can struggle with complex queries), the importance of prompt formatting, and the practical aspects of performance and memory. This knowledge is already influencing how I think about AI features in my product roadmap. I find myself asking better questions of my engineering teams and more critically evaluating vendor claims about ‚ÄúAI-powered‚Äù features.


Modernizing a Legacy Codebase: VB.NET to C# with Roslyn and AI

Fifteen years ago, I led a team of 10 developers as the technical lead on a major modernization project: migrating a large VB.NET codebase to C#. Back then, this was a massive undertaking. We relied on a brute-force rewrite approach, manually converting thousands of lines of code, coordinating across modules, and spending over six months to deliver a reliable result.
Recently, I revisited this challenge as a proof of concept (POC) to understand the impact of AI on our daily work. My goal was to see how modern open-source tools and AI could streamline what once required a large team and significant time investment. After a really long time, i rolled up my sleeves i starting coding in C# with VS-Code.

 

Ingest: Feeding the Entire Codebase as Input

The first step was ingesting the legacy VB.NET project. I decided to make the process as straightforward as possible: simply point the tool to the root folder of the codebase. The ingestion component recursively scanned the folder and gathered all source files. This approach ensured that full context was captured (all modules, classes, and dependencies) in one go, which would be vital for accurate analysis and conversion later. 

string inputFolder = @"C:\LegacyVBProject";
var vbFiles = Directory.GetFiles(inputFolder, "*.vb", SearchOption.AllDirectories);
Console.WriteLine($"Found {vbFiles.Length} VB files to process.");

By ingesting the entire folder, I removed the need for manually listing files or dealing with one file at a time. From a product perspective, this decision would reduce human error and save time- I can feed in an entire project and trust that all relevant code was captured for analysis. This also sets a solid foundation for the subsequent Roslyn analysis by ensuring we weren‚Äôt missing any pieces of the puzzle.

 

Analyze: Leveraging Roslyn for Deep Code Insights

With all code files in hand, the next phase was to analyze the VB.NET source using Microsoft‚Äôs Roslyn. Roslyn is the codename for the open-source .NET Compiler Platform, providing APIs to parse and inspect code for both C# and VB.NET. Essentially, Roslyn can read source code and produce a rich abstract syntax tree (AST) representation, along with semantic information. This was incredibly powerful- it meant that my tool could understand the structure of the VB.NET code programmatically. Why Roslyn? From a product manager‚Äôs viewpoint, I saw Roslyn to de-risk the conversion. By analyzing the code upfront, I could catch potential issues (like unsupported language features or complex syntax quirks) early. Roslyn‚Äôs API allowed us to load the entire project in a workspace and even compile it in memory to ensure there were no lurking compilation errors. Here‚Äôs a simplified look at how I used Roslyn in the tool:

MSBuildLocator.RegisterDefaults();
using var workspace = MSBuildWorkspace.Create();
var solution = await workspace.OpenSolutionAsync(slnPath);
var files = new List<object>();
var deps  = new List<(string From, string To)>();

foreach (var proj in solution.Projects.Where(p => p.Language == LanguageNames.VisualBasic))
{
    var compilation = await proj.GetCompilationAsync();
    foreach (var doc in proj.Documents)
    {
        var tree = await doc.GetSyntaxTreeAsync();
        var model = compilation!.GetSemanticModel(tree);

        if (tree is null) continue;
        var root  = await tree.GetRootAsync();
        var symbols = new List<object>();

        foreach (var node in root.DescendantNodes())
        {
            var symbol = model.GetDeclaredSymbol(node);
            if (symbol is IMethodSymbol ms)
            {
                symbols.Add(new {
                    Kind = "Method",
                    Name = ms.ToDisplayString(),
                    Parameters = ms.Parameters.Select(p => new { p.Name, Type = p.Type.ToDisplayString() }),
                    Returns = ms.ReturnType.ToDisplayString(),
                    Accessibility = ms.DeclaredAccessibility.ToString()
                });

                foreach (var child in node.DescendantNodes())
                {
                    var called = model.GetSymbolInfo(child).Symbol as IMethodSymbol;
                    if (called != null)
                    {
                        deps.Add((ms.ToDisplayString(), called.ToDisplayString()));
                    }
                }
            }
            else if (symbol is INamedTypeSymbol ts)
            {
                symbols.Add(new {
                    Kind = "Type",
                    Name = ts.ToDisplayString(),
                    Accessibility = ts.DeclaredAccessibility.ToString(),
                    TypeKind = ts.TypeKind.ToString()
                });
            }
        }
        files.Add(new {
            Project = proj.Name,
            FilePath = doc.FilePath,
            Symbols = symbols
        });
    }
}

By understanding and implementing Roslyn SDK and then running it over the entire codebase, i now had a semantic model and a syntax tree as a starting point. Using Roslyn, I extracted metadata like the list of classes, their methods, and even metrics such as lines of code per method. One major benefit was Roslyn‚Äôs semantic model- we can resolve variable types, inheritance hierarchies, and references across the project. For example, if a VB module used an ambiguous API, Roslyn helped pinpoint exactly which library it referred to. These insights are not just academic; it directly informs and assists the conversion strategy. I valued how Roslyn provided transparency into the legacy code. It was like shining a flashlight into a black box- suddenly a new developer had a clear map of what they were dealing with. Knowing the code‚Äôs structure allowed me to plan the AI summarization better (for instance, we could break the code into logical units for the LLM). 

 

Summarize: Explaining Code with an LLM

Understanding code isn‚Äôt just a compilation exercise ‚Äì it‚Äôs also about human comprehension. This is where Large Language Model (LLM) step came in. I used the llama model to generate natural-language summaries for the VB.NET code. The goal was to produce clear explanations of what each part of the code did, which would serve as documentation and help verify the converted C# logic later. To do this, I tool fed code snippets into the LLM with prompts like ‚ÄúExplain what this function does.‚Äù The result was a concise paragraph describing the code‚Äôs purpose and behavior in plain English. This process known as code summarization ‚Äì automatically produces a natural language description of a code snippet. Such code summaries are immensely valuable for software maintenance, effectively creating documentation for complex functions and making large codebases easier to navigate.

 

var codeMapPath = Path.Combine(analysisDir, "code_map.json");
var codeMap = JsonNode.Parse(await File.ReadAllTextAsync(codeMapPath))!.AsArray();
var sumDir = Path.Combine(jobDir, "summaries");
Directory.CreateDirectory(sumDir);

foreach (var fileEntry in codeMap)
{
    var filePath = (string?)fileEntry!["FilePath"] ?? "";
    var symbols = fileEntry!["Symbols"]?.ToJsonString() ?? "[]";
    var prompt = $@"
            Explain this VB.NET file in clear, simple terms for a new joinee in the team.

            Context:
            - File path: {filePath}
            - Symbols: {symbols}

            Format: Markdown.
            ";
    var req = new
    {
        model = LLM_MODEL,
        messages = new object[] {
            new { role="system", content="You are a concise, accurate code explainer." },
            new { role="user", content=prompt }
        },
        temperature = 0.2
    };

    using var http = new HttpClient { BaseAddress = new Uri(LLM_BASE) };
    var resp = await http.PostAsync("/chat/completions", 
                                    new StringContent(JsonSerializer.Serialize(req), 
                                    Encoding.UTF8, "application/json"));
    var json = JsonNode.Parse(await resp.Content.ReadAsStringAsync())!;
    var content = (string?)json?["choices"]?[0]?["message"]?["content"] ?? "";

    var mdOut = Path.Combine(sumDir, $"{Path.GetFileName(filePath)}.md");
    await File.WriteAllTextAsync(mdOut, content);

Note that codeMap variable is nothing but the output of Roslyn's analysis containing semantic models and syntax trees. The output was one markdown file per .vb file- containing a natural language summary of what that file does. The LLM is a helper here, which is creating fresh documentation of code without manual analysis. 

 

Convert: Translating VB.NET to C# with Roslyn-Based Tools

Finally, we get to the core of the project- converting the code from VB.NET to C#. After ingestion, analysis and summarization, we proceeded to translate the code itself. Rather than hand-coding the translation (which would be a massive effort and risk human error), I again utilized an open-source code conversion tool built on Roslyn. This tool essentially acts as a translator between the two languages, parsing VB.NET with Roslyn and outputting equivalent C# code. Thanks to Roslyn‚Äôs ability to consider the full project context during conversion. This means it knows about cross-file references, project-wide imports, etc., ensuring a more accurate result. 

 

Conclusion: A Smooth Journey with Open-Source and AI

What once required 10 developers and over 6 months 15 yrs back, can now be executed single-handedly by one skilled developer using AI tools which are air-gapped for privacy.  The POC demonstrated not just technical feasibility, but also how AI can accelerate understanding, documentation, and validation- making legacy modernization far more accessible and efficient.

 

The Evolving Role of the Product Manager

This POC was not just about technical transformation POC- it was about understanding the impact of AI in our daily work. As a product manager, I realized that to smartly leverage AI in products and design new features, one must evolve to understand the inner workings of these technologies. AI is no longer just a backend tool; it‚Äôs a strategic asset that can reshape workflows, reduce costs, and unlock new possibilities for innovation. This POC helped me understand how modern AI tools are accelerating work at an unseen pace and accuracy, and also kickstarted my journey into learning from a familiar project- one which i reimagined with AI.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to recieve normal stock for WBS projec...
entry.content:
There are couple of issues with your requirement and setup.

1.  In order to manage inventory on a project you have to select Valuated or Non-Valuated Stock.  You cannot select No Project Stock.  No Project Stock means that POs are immediately expensed to a project and never visible in inventory management.

2. You should select Valuated Stock.

3. You can't mix Project Stock demands and Plant Stock inventory, you have to pick one or the other.  Sounds like your requirement is to use Plant Stock inventory.

4. In a PS project you add material component demands to a Network Activity using "L" Stock Item.  This is your project material planning. 

5. In the Material Master for the components set the Ind/Coll indicator to 2 for Collective Only on the MRP4 tab.  This will insure the demands are all grouped together under Plant Stock.

6. With steps 4 and 5 you can run MRP and it will match the demand to current inventory or create a planned order for make parts or a PR for buy parts.

7.  You do not need to create PIRs

entry.title: SAP Developer News 23rd October, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION 

PODCAST: https://podcast.opensap.info/sap-developers/2025/10/23/sap-developer-news-october-23rd-2025/ 

Innersource Summit 2025 

  • Blog post: https://community.sap.com/t5/berlin-blog-posts/sap-mitsubishi-electric-and-ibm-will-co-host-the-innersource-summit-join-us/ba-p/14240606?source=social-Global-YouTube-No-Developer_Community-SAPTechEd-Audience_Engagement_%2F_Develop_Community-Community_Topic-Video-18471776374&campaigncode=CRM-YA23-SMS-1941768&sprinklrid=18471776374 
  • LinkedIn post: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/dellagustin_innersource-summit-2025-activity-7383549127776690176-nZPG/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAAXV8RABBNOYkSYKm-L3OOMbqxFSWK5zb8g 
  • Event link: https://innersourcecommons.org/events/isc-2025/ 
  • Mastodon/Fediverse:  https://fosstodon.org/@dellagustin/115367633710981210 
  • BlueSky: https://bsky.app/profile/innersource.bsky.social/post/3m2rzrmmspk2j 
  • X/Twitter: https://x.com/sapopensource/status/1976679116695888151 

BTP Trial Update: CF Runtime Availability 

  • Blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/btp-trial-update-cf-runtime-availability/ba-p/14247240 

SAP Business Data Cloud deep-dives 

  • SAP Business Data Cloud ‚Äì An Architecture Deep Dive: https://community.sap.com/t5/devtoberfest/sap-business-data-cloud-an-architecture-deep-dive/ev-p/14214642 
  • Provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud Connect: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/provisioning-sap-business-data-cloud-connect-and-enrolling-with-existing/ba-p/14237512  
  • People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud is Generally Available: https://community.sap.com/t5/delivery-blog-posts/people-intelligence-in-sap-business-data-cloud-is-generally-available/ba-p/14240825  
  • Data and Analytics (DA) at SAP TechEd: https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin/flow/sap/te25/tracks-inperson/page/data-and-analytics   

Developing Mobile Apps with AI Agents: Introducing the MCP Server for MDK 

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/developing-mobile-apps-with-ai-agents-introducing-the-mcp-server-for-mobile/ba-p/14237709 
  • https://github.com/SAP/mdk-mcp-server 

SAP TechEd 2025 

  • Event Site: https://www.sap.com/events/teched.html 

 

CHAPTER TITLES  

0:00 Intro 

0:10 Innersource Summit 2025 

1:09 BTP Trial Update: CF Runtime Availability 

2:00 SAP Business Data Cloud deep-dives 

3:10 Developing Mobile Apps with AI Agents: Introducing the MCP Server for MDK 

4:08 SAP TechEd 

 

TRANSCRIPTION

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for October 23rd, 2025.

[Ajay] Everyone. Have you ever heard about Innersource? It is the practice of applying open source methodologies, culture, and best practices to the in-house software development. SAP is co-hosting and co-organizing the Innersource Summit in Berlin this year. If you want to know more about it, it is a great opportunity for you. The InnerSource Summit 2025 will take place on November 13th, 2025 across Berlin, Yokohama, and New York. It is hosted by SAP, Mitsubishi Electric, and IBM. The agenda is filled with topics about open-source-inspired collaborations, InnerSource analytics, state of InnerSource in the industry, measuring cross-team collaboration, scientific research about InnerSource, and much more. Join the event in person on-site or virtually online. Check the blog post by Gillyherme to find the agenda and how to get the tickets. Links will be available in the description below.

[DJ] Here is an important item for users of the SAP BTP trial account landscape. It concerns the Cloud Foundry runtime specifically. Owing to a high amount of misuse of this part of the platform, the offering for the Cloud Foundry runtime will be drastically restricted for the time being. The main difference for us is that for this period we won't be able to deploy to a CF runtime. Remember, this is regarding the trial landscape only. We strongly advise you to check out Karen Burke's blog post and stay tuned to that for updates. You can also, of course, ask questions there as comments on that blog post if you need to. Link to the blog post is in the description.

[Witalij] As the Devtoberfest first concludes, we hope you joined the sessions on SAP Business Data Cloud, including the architectural deep dive led by the product CTO. While Bjorn delivered a comprehensive overview, the 30-minute format limited the depth of the coverage for key topics such as data products, BW and BDC, or SAP Databricks, but each of which was explored in dedicated sessions earlier this month. Refer to the dedicated blog post for additional insights on Business Data Cloud Connect. BDC Connect is a newly launched service designed to facilitate secure, bi-directional, and zero-copy data product sharing between SAP BDC and external partner systems. Early adopters include Databricks and Google Cloud. Nedel Eduardo provides a detailed walkthrough in a separate post for technical specifics on provisioning BDC Connect. We look forward to seeing you at SAP TechEd on tour and virtually in November, where hands-on workshops will offer practical experience with these advancements. Stay tuned for more.

[Kevin] Hey everybody, if you are a mobile developer, kit developer building cross-platform applications for mobile devices, I got good news for you. The team just released the MDK MCP server on GitHub. It's open source and you can easily install it via NPM on your local machine. You can use the MCP server from out of Klein or GitHub Copilot to not only bootstrap new MDK applications but also enhance your existing ones with new features. It has a port for access to the MDK CLI tools. So you have the whole tool set at your fingertips to build great mobile applications. If you want to find out more, there is a blog post in the community explaining all the details and linking to all the additional resources for you. As always, you can find the link to the blog post in the description of our news video.

[Tom] As this episode of the developer news reaches you, we're nearing the end of Devtoberfest. It's been a great four weeks and I hope that you've enjoyed the time and learned a lot. But you know what the end of Devtoberfest means ‚Äî the start of SAP TechEd. Whether you plan to join us in person in Berlin, on the virtual platform, or at one of the many TechEd on tour stops around the world, we look forward to bringing you TechEd. Our team at the Developer Advocates is busy getting ready for the developer garage, hands-on workshops, community talks, as well as, of course, the developer keynote. We can't wait to show you all the great new things that are planned for this year, and we look forward to seeing you at TechEd.

entry.title: Help Us Shape the CX Intelligent App: Call for Customer Design Partners
entry.content:
TL;DR: We‚Äôre inviting CROs, CMOs, COOs, and their teams to co‚Äëcreate the new CX Intelligent Application‚Äîan insight app that unifies data from SAP Sales Cloud, SAP Commerce Cloud, and SAP S/4HANA, powered by SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Technology Platform. Join brief intro calls, periodic update sessions, and hands‚Äëon feedback workshops to influence the roadmap and experience from day one.

Why this matters for revenue, marketing, and operations leaders

Leaders today are expected to steer growth with speed and precision‚Äîyet critical signals often live in different systems. The CX Intelligent Application puts your sales and commerce signals in one place and turns them into unified, actionable insights you can use to prioritize, decide, and act - faster.

What is the CX Intelligent App?

The CX Intelligent Application is an advanced insight app designed for CRO, CMO, and COO teams. It seamlessly combines data from SAP Sales Cloud, SAP Commerce Cloud, and SAP S/4HANA, leveraging the power of SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Technology Platform.

What you can expect:

  • One view of revenue & commerce health across channels, customers, and products
  • Decision‚Äëready insights that highlight trends, risks, and opportunities
  • Clear, executive‚Äëfriendly narratives that frame ‚Äúwhat changed, why it matters, and what to do next‚Äù
  • Actionability rooted in your SAP landscape, designed to fit exec workflows

SAP product focus: SAP Sales Cloud ‚Ä¢ SAP Commerce Cloud ‚Ä¢ SAP Engagement Cloud

What we‚Äôre doing - and where you come in

Our goal is to validate value and usability with C‚Äëlevel leaders and their direct staff. We want your candid feedback on how the app supports data‚Äëdriven decisions, integrates multi‚Äësolution insights, and enables more efficient sales and commerce processes.

How we‚Äôll collaborate

  1. Kickoff (short intro call): We‚Äôll walk through the concept and architecture and align on success criteria.
  2. Regular update sessions: We‚Äôll share progress, upcoming features, and open questions, and we‚Äôll listen to your pain points and ideas.
  3. Hands‚Äëon feedback workshops: Explore click‚Äëthrough prototypes and provide input on user experience, KPIs, and the insights that matter most to you.

Your expertise will directly shape what we prioritize next.

Who should participate?

  • Chief Revenue Officers, Chief Marketing Officers, Chief Operating Officers
  • Strategy, Ops, and Analytics leaders supporting the C‚Äësuite
  • Organizations using (or planning to use) SAP Sales Cloud, SAP Commerce Cloud, SAP Engagement Cloud, and/or SAP S/4HANA

What‚Äôs in it for you

  • Early influence: Directly shape an executive‚Äëgrade insight app before GA
  • Relevance: Ensure the insights reflect your KPIs, motions, and governance
  • Speed to value: Help us remove friction between data, insight, and action
  • Visibility: Option for an executive readout summarizing what we learned together

What the commitment looks like

  • A brief intro call to align on goals
  • Periodic update sessions to review progress and share feedback
  • Targeted workshops to test prototypes and suggest enhancements

(We‚Äôll keep participation lightweight and respectful of executive time.)

How to join

  • Step 1: Indicate your interest: Sign up here 
  • Step 2: We‚Äôll schedule the intro call and share next steps
  • Step 3: You‚Äôll be invited to updates and hands‚Äëon workshops

Prefer email? Reach out to kim.haller@sap.com
You can also comment below and we‚Äôll reach out.

entry.title: Wrong material valuation - correction?
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Finance 

Dear community, 

we noticed a problem in our material ledger (material valuation). Couple of our products were correctly costed (Costing 2 tab in product master data) but the price was not correctly updated in Accounting 1 tab in some ledgers/currencies. We also noticed that the costing lot size was 100, price unit at the costing 2 tab was 100, but in the accounting tab it was 100 only under 2L ledger and currency 10 (all other ledgers and currencies had price unit 1) => this should not cause the issue because the system is recalculating it but for some reason it didn't. 

(amounts are just illustrative). 
A product was costed 10,000 HUF / 24.57 EUR per 100 pieces (Costing 2 tab). This amount was also correct in our 2L ledger and currency 10 in the accounting 1 tab. 
Other currencies under 2L (30 + functional currency) and all under 0L (10,30,FC) were determined incorrectly:  10,000 HUF / 24.57 EUR per 1piece.  (2,457 per 100 pieces)

This caused wrong booking when a production order was confirmed. Now we have:

2L (currency 10): 1,000 pieces with total value of 100,000 HUF (correct)
0L (currency 10): 1,000 pieces with total value of 10,000,000 HUF (wrong)
2L (currency 30,FC): 1,000 pieces with total value of 24,570 EUR (wrong)
0L (currency 30,FC): 1,000 pieces with total value of 24,570 EUR (wrong)

We ran a new costing which corrected the Accounting 1 tab so we believe that the future posting should be ok. But we don't know how to correct the wrong balance sheet amounts (the costing itself didn't post revaluation because the costing 2 tab didn't change). 

We found couple of applications like Adjust Inventory Balance Sheet Accounts - Delta Posting but we don't know if it solves the problem. 

Thank you!
Pavel

entry.title: AWS Route 53 setup for multiple Hana Cloud instances with Private Link
entry.content:
So, I'm planning  on spinning up multiple hana cloud instances, and I want to use AWS private link.

Getting one instance in AWS us-east to work was easy; just configure Route 53 to point

*.hana.prod-us10.hanacloud.ondemand.com -> the vpc endpoint

But let's say I've got another instance I want to connect to, within the same VPC.... should be easy? Just reconfigure Route 53 to do:
<uuid>.hana.prod-us10.hanacloud.ondemand.com -> the vpc endpoint

Well, that does not work!

I discovered that hana cloud actually "redirects" to an internal hostname, upon connection. The hostname is in a form that's basically impossible to define in route53 as it requires a 5-digit unknown suffix (and route53 can't do wildcards in a partial subdomain). Here's the spec: https://me.sap.com/notes/3325646

The note does mention an unsupported option that would prevent the redirect, which would then make it easy to map things in route 53. But, it advises against doing that...

Seems to me like unless the service endpoint id is the same for every hana instance in us-east-1,  I don't see how it's possible to use private link when having multiple instances.

I did try setting up a custom domain, but getting TLS errors when connecting using that. This could work, I just don't know how to set that up correctly.

I know there must be a way, so am wondering, has anybody figured this out?

entry.title: Re: Manage Supplier Quotation App Always Creates PO with...
entry.content:
Good day @Vinith 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage Supplier Quotations, Sourcing and Procurement

Sourcing & Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2308

Service Order (A2X)

To summarise, in public cloud, that behaviour is controlled by the public cloud scope and you cannot change or influence it though configuration.

That happens because of a few reasons:

  1. The procurement of Direct Materials always calls the standard PO type NB. That logic is part of the SAP standard process integration between Supplier Quotation and Purchase Order object.
  2. In Public Cloud, custom document type determination is not released.

Even though you can create custom document types in ‚ÄúDefine Document Types for Purchase Orders‚Äù configuration, they are usable only when you create Pos manually in Manage Purchase Orders and not during automated follow-on creation from other apps.

The best practice is to either:

1. Stick with the Clean Core approach of manual creation with custom type:

Open Manage Purchase Orders --> Create a new Po with your custom document type --> Reference the supplier quotation under the Source of Supply section.

2. Optionally, use side-by-side to build BTP automation that reads the awarded quotation and calls the Public API Purchase Order ‚Äì Create From Quotation endpoint. You can pass the custom document type (ZNB) in the payload.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris
