entry.title: Re: Not able to access https://connectsupport.ariba.com/
entry.content:
Regarding to your issue, please refer to KBA 3121688 - S-user ID authorizations for Designated Support Contact (DSC) access or Basic access - SAP Ariba Connect

The Ariba installation for your company account is 90971866, the two S-users you provided are missing authorizations on this installation.

Authorizations needed for Basic access:

  • Display Cloud Data - set at the Ariba installation number level

Authorizations needed for Designated Support Contact (DSC) access:

  • Display Cloud Data - set at the Ariba installation number level
  • Report Technical Problem - set at Customer Number level or Ariba installation number level
  • Close Cases - set at Customer Number level or Ariba installation number level
  • Send Cases to SAP - set at Customer Number level or Ariba installation number level
  • Display Cases - set at Customer Number level or Ariba installation number level

For data security, our SAP always recommend customer to manage S-users/authorizations by themselves. 

Thus please contact below Ariba cloud admin to help assign authorizations these two S-users.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM - Business Service Management - Integration with third-party ITSM Solutions (Part 1)
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

This blog post is part of a small series of posts intended to provide details about SAP Cloud ALM - Business Service Management (BSM) use case. The goal of this blog post is to highlight how BSM use case can support SAP customers during daily operations of SAP cloud landscapes. Also, to provide details how to perform integration of Events offered by BSM use case with third-party ITSM solutions.

The content of the this blog post is following:

Part 1:  Business Service Management - OverviewPart 2: Business Service Management - Event Integration with Third-Party systems
  • Motivation
  • Status Events (Event Types) and Details
  • Integration Scenarios 
  • Defining Business Services
  • External API Management - Event Situations (Status Events)
  • External API Management - How to define Field Mapping
  • External API Management - Webhooks and Subscriptions
  • External API Management - Testing and Troubleshooting

Business Service Management (BSM) - Overview

Motivation:

In SAP Cloud ALM, the Business Service Management use case offers a central location for customers to access information about the 'Status Events' of their SAP Cloud Services. SAP cloud customers can find communication updates like Planned Maintenance, Disruptions, Degradations and other communication notices about their SAP cloud services.

SAP Cloud ALM Business Service Management provides a central IT Calendar where customer can get visibility about SAP Cloud Services and Technical System statuses. Customers can understand whether Cloud Service\System is operational, whether there is any Disruption or Degradation affecting services or when Planned Maintenances are scheduled. Also, t he IT Calendar offered by BSM provides visibility about past and upcoming 'Status Events'.

The source of information for Cloud ALM Business Service Management is the SAP Cloud Availability Center.  SAP Cloud ALM resuses this information within CALM to enhance Operations use cases, but also helps customers to handle these notifications in a more efficient way. For example, by performing integration with third-party ITSM solutions to support SLA tracking or trigger contingency plans in case of Disruptions/Degradations. In addition, Business Service Management in SAP Cloud ALM also provides capabiltites like capabilities such as standard Service Level Reports with possiblity to use custom service level objectives.

SAP Cloud Availability Center offers these 'Status Events' notifications for certain 'Supported Products' . These products are also supported within SAP Cloud ALM..  There are different 'Status Events' types offered (Planned Maintenance, Disruptions, Degradations, and Important Communications), each of these 'Status Events' types has its own lifecycle of communications.
The picture below indicates which type of communication SAP sends to customer depending of the 'Status Event' type:

Integration Scenarios:

SAP customers can leverage Business Service Management to achieve the following integration scenarios with third-party ITSM tools to support daily operations:

  • Planned maintenance events: automatically create change records, schedule windows, and send stakeholder communications aligned to SLAs.
  • Unplanned outages or service disruptions: auto-create incidents, trigger major-incident workflows, and accelerate triage using impact mapping to business services in the CMDB.
  • Performance degradation or partial functional impact: generate alerts, prioritize based on business criticality, and route to the right resolver groups.

The focus of this series of blog posts is to help customers implement the integration of Cloud ALM BSM Events with third-party ITSM solutions for scenarios like the ones mentioned above.

For further information about Business Service Management, check following materials:

  • Cloud ALM Expert Portal - Business Service Management
  • Business Service Management - Overview Presentation
Defining Business Services

The first activity to be performed when starting to leverage Cloud ALM Business Service Management use case is to define the so-called Business Services within the application.  It is mandatory to define one (or more) Business Services in SAP Cloud ALM before configuring 'Notifications' or 'Third-Party Integration' for the 'Status Events' forCloud Services\Systems. 
Next steps show how to define Business Services in SAP Cloud ALM BSM use case:

What are Business Services? 

Initially, let's understand what exactly is a Business Service at Cloud ALM Business Service Management (BSM) use case. The Business Service is basically a container for Cloud Services and Systems which are grouped due to a certain relationship (business or technical functionalities), for example:

  • SAP Production Landscape: A group containing all 'Production' Cloud Services and Systems regardless of their type.
  • SAP non-Production Landscape: A group containing all 'nonProduction' (Sandbox, Development and Quality roles) Cloud Services and Systems regardless of their type.
  • Lead to Cash: A group containing only Cloud Services and Systems relevant to run 'Lead to Cash' process
  • Hire to Retire: A group containing only Cloud Services and Systems relevant to run 'Hire to Retire' process
  • etc.

The Business Services are freely defined by end users to represent groups according to their needs. The Business Services are simple structures, with a name, an additional description, and the relationship to multiple cloud services or technical systems which belonging to the group.

How to define a Business Service in Cloud ALM BSM?

The steps to define a Business Service are quite simple:

1) Access Cloud ALM Business Service Management configuration area:
Access Cloud ALM Launchpad ‚Üí Cloud ALM for Operations ‚Üí Click Business Service Management tile
At he top-right corner, use the ‚ÄòConfiguration‚Äô icons to open configuration pop-up:

Once we have pop-up 'Configuration for Business Services', one can simply quick on 'Add' to create new Business Service.

At 'Basic Information', the first action while creating a new Business Service is to provide a name and a description. Name and Description are freely defined by the end user according to organizational needs.

Then at 'Services / Systems' tab, we select which are the Cloud Services and Systems that will be part of the Business Service. Use the relevant option to add a Cloud Service or Technical System:

NOTE 1: The Cloud Services and Technical Systems available to be added as part of a Business Services are Services\Systems which are registered in the Cloud ALM Landscape Management. SAP Cloud Services and ECS\Rise systems are automatically discovered. 
In case systems are located in a customer managed private landscape, then it is required to register system to Cloud ALM Landscape Management first. 
NOTE 2: Cloud ALM Business Service Management only provides 'Status Events' communications to Services\Systems hosted by  SAP (Cloud Services and ECS\Rise Technical Systems). Customer can still use Business Service Management as central IT Calendar to manage Status Events, but it is customer responsibility to define the events in the IT Calendar accordingly (Planned Maintenance, Disruptions, etc.). 

At tab 'Service Level Objective' (SLO), customers can maintain their own SLOs settings to be tracked by Cloud ALM. Service Level reports are available in Cloud ALM to track SLAs for the Services\Systems part of the Business Service:

In the last tab 'Event Actions' is where the main configuration is performedfor the Business Service. In this tab we can decide actions to be triggered for the available Event Types.
The Cloud ALM Business Service Management offers different type of 'Events' depending on the communication that has to be sent to customer:

  • Disruption: Service is not available due to unplanned disruptive events
  • Degradation: Service usage is limited, for example due to performance problems
  • Maintenance: Service is not available during a defined time interval due to planned and previously announced maintenance activities.
  • Communication: SAP informs about required actions on customer side or planned changes for SAP managed cloud service via customer communication events

For each of these 'Status Events' types, it is possible to trigger Cloud ALM actions for the different lifecycle communcation of the 'Status Event'. As seen before, following communications are avaiable for each 'Status Event' type:

The following actions can be triggered for the avaialble communications:

  • Send Email Notification: Send email notification to relevant users
  • Send Chat Notification: Send notification in a chat channel (e.g., MS Teams)
  • Create Ticket: Create incident in ITSM solution (option that is the focus of this blog series)
  • Start Operation Flow: Trigger an automated task in SAP Build Process Automation / SAP Workflow / Automation Pilot (or third-party solution)

For example: One would like to be notified for the 'Planned Maitenance - Status Events' communications when it gets 'Anounced', also get a 'Remider' and finally gets 'Completed'.
To fulfill this requrement, it is possible to configure the ''Planned Maitenance - Status Event' accordingly to notify end-users with such communications only. The steps below how to achieve this for 'Email Notifications':

Using very similar configuration steps, it is possible to send such communications to the corporate ITSM solution to establish a formal process to trigger follow up activities, e.g. Trigger Contigency Plan/Actions when critical system is not avaiable due to an unplanned 'Disruption' or prepare Business Teams for planned downtime when there is a 'Planned Maintenance' scheduled. 

To perform the integration of Business Service Management with corporate ITSM solution, firstly it is required to establish the technical integration between Cloud ALM and the Corporate ITSM solution. This will be covered in detail in the Part 2 of this blog series.

Best Practices summary for Cloud ALM Business Service Management

The recommended adoption steps for customers are following:

  1. Understand what SAP Cloud Services and Technical Systems (ECS\Rise) are supported by SAP Cloud Availability Center and Cloud ALM Business Service Management
  2. Plan which Business Services should be defined in Cloud ALM Business Service Management to represent SAP landscape
  3. Define which Status Events communications will be leveraged to manage systems
  4. Plan required action plan/process for each Status Events commuication type (Disruption, Planned Maintenance, etc.) whether Email Notification will be used and/or Intgration with Third-Party system is necessary.

I hope this introduction to Cloud ALM Business Service Management use case provides helpful details about the motivation of this feature in SAP Cloud ALM and how customers can benefit from it. In the next blog post we will explore in detail how to perform the integration of this use case with corporate ITSM solution.

  • SAP Cloud ALM - Business Service Management - Integration with third-party ITSM Solutions (Part 2)

Kind Regards,
Allam Drebes

entry.title: Re: Interdependencies between date fields in SAPapps ‚ÄúMan...
entry.content:
Good day @Shubham120798 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Delivery and Transportation Scheduling, Sales Order Processing & Manage Sales Orders

Yes, your observations are correct. I agree that the interaction between date fields can indeed cause confusion or even delivery blocks if your master data and configuration are not aligned.

To summarise, when Planned Delivery Time in MM is unrealistically high, the systems‚Äô backward scheduling pushes the Material Availability Date far into the future. During delivery creation, the system checks ATP: if there is not stock by that date, delivery creation is blocked because no quantity is confirmed.

To better support your process, I suggest you consider the following Best Practices:

  • Run the Check Material Availability in Manage Sales Orders to simulate date logic and see which field drives the schedule.
  • Then Use Display Material √† MRP 2 tab to check the PDT values.
  • Use the Analyse Delivery Schedule or Material Availability Overview to see how each date was derived.
  • Avoid manual overwriting of dates. Rather let scheduling calculate automatically once master data is correct.

Optionally, you can achieve improvements with the Clean-Core by:

  • Activating Situation Handling, which will alert your users when PDT or transportation times cause scheduling delays.
  • Ensure you periodically review and cleanse master data through ‚ÄúData Quality Evaluation for Materials‚Äù app if you have enabled it.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Project Financial Booklet
entry.content:
Good day @jantoniomoyano3 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Investment Projects (1NT), Project Budget Report & Budget Availability Control for Projects

To summarise, the Project Financial Booklet app is not suitable for investment projects. That app supports Professional Services and Customer/Expense projects with revenue components but does not handle capital-investment projects settled to Assets Under Construction (AUC).

For investments projects, use the Project Budget Report, Project Cost Report, and Monitor Budget Consumption to ensure accurate budget tracking and viability control.

Optionally enhance with SAP Analytics Cloud dashboards for consolidated financial visibility.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris
